subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit Failure Trace not printed completely
msgSnippet: I believe you can also press the filter stack trace button on the right side of the runner and the entire trace appears in the window. Randy Cox ... From:
messageBody:
I believe you can also press the filter stack trace button on the right side
of the runner and the entire trace appears in the window.

Randy Cox

-----Original Message-----
From: javainsel [mailto:javainsel@...]
Sent: Thursday, June 12, 2003 12:49 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: JUnit Failure Trace not printed completely


The problem is that we use a bad style JUnit test in my eyes because
of this problem.

public void testXyz()
{
try
{
// a exception occurs
}
catch(Exception e)
{
e.printStackTrace();
}
}

instead of:

public void testXyz() throws Exception
{
// a exception occurs
}

Now try to convince the coworkers to copy the trace to an editor
instead of writing the stack trace to the console...

Any ideas?



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@f...> wrote:
> If you are referring to the embedded runner:
> Right Click > Copy trace
> Paste into another editor.
>
> It may not be the runner cropping it though.
>
> =jason
>
> On Thu, 2003-06-12 at 11:13, javainsel wrote:
> > If the line of a failure trace is too witdth then in the JUnit
view
> > the line
> > is cropped which means that I cannot read the whole line.
> >
> > What solution is there for this problem?
> >
> > I use Eclipse 2.0.2.
